**ULA's Vulcan Rocket**

ULA has announced a new rocket called Vulcan. It has two Blue Origin BE-4 engines on the first stage, and will begin with a Centaur upper stage and move on to the ACES upper stage. The first stage engines will separate from the first stage, decelerate in the atmosphere by some system, and be retrieved mid-air. The design no longer uses the Russian built and designed RD-180 engine. Live stream is over but was presented here: [http://www.ulalaunch.com/webcast.aspx](http://www.ulalaunch.com/webcast.aspx)

Some things that were mentioned:

- More powerful solid rocket boosters
- Based off of both Atlas and Delta heritage
- Twin BE-4 engines using methane / liquefied natural gas (I think they mentioned methane in the livestream)
- Initially uses Centaur, then switches to ACES
- Similar fairings, but different
- No direct cost given, but I think Tony Bruno mentioned that a general rule for rockets is 1 billion USD for new engine, 1 billion USD for new rocket on top. Not sure if I heard correctly but I think that's it.

*Please discuss below if you would like!*

**Edited <time datetime="2015-04-13T21:15:18Z" title="04/13/2015 09:15  PM" data-short="9 yr">April 13, 2015</time> by Woopert**

Hah! That was my name choice in the voting, too.

Hilariously ULA only offered it reluctlantly, because the original three choices (the top internal employee suggestions) were all sneered at by the public ![:D](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_cheesy.gif)

But, Vulcan is a good name for a rocket. May it fly as well as the Atlas V.

Today United Launch Alliance introduced it's new rocket design called 'Vulcan' also known the NGLS (Next Generation Launch System). Probably the most interesting part is it's reusable engines and the fact that they intend to recover it mid-air with a cargo helicopter, after it being detached from the first stage fuel tank (like the old Atlas booster engines did). According to the plan, it will also use an inflatable heat shield during re-entry. ULA expects to reduce launch costs by quite much:

![CCf3CkkW4AAVAPM.jpg:large](https://pbs.twimg.com/media/CCf3CkkW4AAVAPM.jpg:large)

What do you think of this technology? How reliable could this system be? Could it rival SpaceX's reusable boosters? Let me know about your thoughts!
Loving what I'm seeing here. But how do you feed fuel through a heatshield?

Engines are typically the most expensive part..

But I don't think it'll be much better than the SSMEs. Re certifying them cost a lot. Considering they had to pretty much rebuild them.

> 
> Loving what I'm seeing here. But how do you feed fuel through a heatshield?

The heat shield seems to be quite small when it's deflated. If you take a look at the engine cycle picture there's plenty of space around it. Hence why they decided to go with an inflatable one.
Its inflatable, presumably the fuel lines go around it till the engine module is cut free, then the shield inflates.

> 
> Loving what I'm seeing here. But how do you feed fuel through a heatshield?

Inflatable heat shield.

I see a thread merging on the horizon...

But it is cool looking. I like the Atlas V style SRBs.
Probably. I also wonder if it could work well with heavy or super heavy lifters.
Oh, inflatable I see. Cool rocket. Give it a month we'll have one in KSP.

The heat shield starts fully deflated & folded ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif) there should be plenty of space around the deflated heatshield to get fuel lines through ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)

Yet, that'll increase a lot the complexity of the 1st stage, if they have to make a reliable separation mecanism to sever (and maybe seal too to protect the plumbing) when jetisonning the engines.

Yet, having to get an retrieving vehicle on standby so far at sea - with risks of adverse weather at the recuperation point - guess they won't reuse as much engines as they'll want to ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)

And seriously ULA - go with ACES with new engines ASAP ![:P](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_tongue.gif) RL-10 engines costs an arm & a leg too due to their manufacturing process ![:P](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_tongue.gif) (especially if you need to put 4 of them pn an upper stage)

Anyhow, it follows mythology like Atlas, and is using some interesting design decisions. It's not much like the original Vulkan.

> Whats the payload?

24,000lb (10.7 tons) to GTO with centaur.

> 
> 24,000lb (10.7 tons) to GTO with centaur.

So.. about 20 something tonnes to LEO?
Probably something like that, assuming availability of DEC. A pretty reasonable assumption, given DEC's been funded for CST-100.
If they want to replace both Delta IV and Atlas V than it has to be able to launch at least 22 tonnes to LEO.
